title: Update submodule dmlc-core
body:
Command I use to update submodule:
````
git submodule update --remote 3rdparty/dmlc-core
````

The commits included:
````
git diff --submodule
Submodule 3rdparty/dmlc-core 946a5401..4d49691f:
  > Redesign dmlc::TemporaryDirectory to allow recursive deletion (#469)
  > Include librt in CMakeLists.txt to access clock_gettime() (#467)
  > Add AppVeyor to run unit tests on Windows (#468)
  > Expose TemporaryDirectory as a feature (#464)
  > Revert "Support to allow user to pass specific environment variables (server/worker/both) (#346)" (#466)
  > Consolidate fopen64 warning (#465)
  > Support to allow user to pass specific environment variables (server/worker/both) (#346)
  > Link with libhdfs statically (#262)
  > Fix #456: Enable usleep for non-MSVC on Windows (#462)
  > Fix #457: fopen64 macro shouldn't override content of stdio.h (#458)
  > Fix gtest can not find source build issue (#459)
  > Remove redundant include_directories. (#454)
````

title: [RELAY][Refactor] TextPrinter, move ret_type after body in Function.
body:
This is a refactor to make the relay IR easier to use for users who are more familiar with graph style DSL. It contains the following changes. I make them in one PR because they are tied together on making the construction and debugging of IR easy.

- [x] A new TextPrinter, which replaces the original debug printer by @MarisaKirisame 
    - It uses a graph style printing for nested common Exprs in a DAG.
    - It introduces a meta-data section, that allows us to serialize any tvm node as metadata.
    - Print of the call attribute is now supported, which only prints out the non-default arguments.
    - The text format generally follows the proposal by @joshpoll in #1782 with the following difference
       - Tensor type are in form of Tensor[shape, base_type] (to be consistent with the constructor)
       - use full name function instead of fn
       - The text format is not finalized and can subject to discussion.
- [x] Refactor Function, change the position of ret_type and body
    - The rationale behind this is that usually, people construct function without specifying return types.
- [x] introduce relay.var, relay.const as a quick wrapper to create var and const.
- [x] Fix most serialization problem of relay IR, issues bought up by @slyubomirsky 
    - Need to followup PR with serialization testcases

I will post a more elaborated discussion on what does it mean to have a graph-aware IR later

## Example 0: Graph Print Format
```python
def test_graph():
    x = relay.var("x", "float32")
    y = relay.var("y", "float32")
    z = relay.add(x, y)
    z = relay.add(z, z)
    f = relay.Function([x, y], z)    
    env = relay.Environment()
    env.add("myf", f)
    print(env.astext())
```

Will display the following result. Please note how the temporary variable %1 %0 are created to reflect the exact structure of the Expr relation. These are not explicit let, but just temporary graph variables. 

```
def @myf(%x: float32,
         %y: float32) {
  %0 = add(%x, %y) # ty=float32
  %1 = add(%0, %0) # ty=float32
  %1
}
```

## Example1: Conv with Meta Data

```python
def test_func():
    n, c, h, w = tvm.var("n"), 10, 224, 224
    x = relay.var("x", shape=(n, c, h, w))
    w = relay.var("w")
    z = relay.nn.conv2d(x, w,
                        kernel_size=(3, 3),
                        padding=(1, 1),
                        channels=2)
    f = relay.Function([x, w], z)
    print(f.astext())
```

will get the following IR
```
function(%x: Tensor[(meta.Variable(id=0), 10, 224, 224), float32],
         %w) {
  %0 = nn.conv2d(%x, %w, padding=[1, 1], channels=2, kernel_size=[3, 3])
  %0
}
# meta data ommitted
```

## Example2: Mix Let and the Temporary Graph Node
```python
def test_let_if_scope():
    x = relay.var("x", "float32")
    y = relay.var("y", "float32")
    cond = relay.var("cond", "bool")
    v1 = relay.var("v")
    v2 = relay.var("v", "float32")
    then_branch = relay.Let(
        v1, relay.const(1, "float32"),
        relay.Let(v2, x, relay.subtract(v1, v2)))
    v3 = relay.var("v")
    let2 = relay.Let(v3, y, v3)
    else_branch = relay.add(let2, let2)
    result = relay.If(cond, then_branch, else_branch)
    f = relay.Function([x, y, cond], result)
    show(f.astext())
```
Will display
```
function(%x: float32,
         %y: float32,
         %cond: bool) {
  if (%cond) {
    let %v = 1f
    let %v1: float32 = %x
    %0 = subtract(%v, %v1)
    %0
  }  else {
    %1 = {
      let %v2 = %y
      %v2
    }
    %2 = add(%1, %1)
    %2
  }
}
```

## Discussion
One noticable thing in the examples is that IR builder is not used, instead the expression is directly composed together with calls, wth function construction in the end. This is a preferrable way of doing DSL construction, as user usually construct a new gradually and collects the weight, instead of declaring weight in the beginning. This might also remove the need of IR Builder in common nn usecases.

The current TextPrinter is not yet perfect. The temporary graph node themselfs do not have scope, and the current TextPrinter can have funny result when there are shared  temporary graph node between parallel scopes(they will appear in the first scope), but if we disrecard the scope and just reconstruct the expression, the parsed expr is still valid. A better way is to make it appear on the common parent scope, which is doable with a future PR.

title: [RELAY][IR] Move type_annotation to Var, remove Param
body:
- [x] Move type_annotation as a field of Var
   - Remove value_type in Let
   - Remove Param and use Var instead
- [x] Add/correct docstring of all python Expr class, make them self-contained.

The reasoning behind the change:
- The current Param was a bit confusing and is only used in the place of the function parameter declaration. Folding the type annotation into Var allows removing one concept.
- This will make the future graph style programming easier, which I will follow up with subsequent PR.

title: [TOPI] Update pre-tuned parameters for TX2 and fp16 on Mali
body:
* Mics fixes
* Add tuned parameters for TX2
batch size =1, dtype = float32, unit = ms

| | densenet121 | inception v3 | mobilenet | resnet50 | vgg16 | vgg19 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| GTX TITAN X | 5.8 | 9.7 | 1.0 | 4.3 | 6.4 | 7.5 |
| Tegra X2  | 26.4 | 45.4 | 5.1 | 25.8 | 57.2 | 67.6 |

TVM achieves parity with TensorRT fp32 performance, similar to other NVIDIA gpu cards.

* Add tuned parameters for fp16 on Mali-T860
batch size = 1, unit = ms


| | densenet121 | inception v3 | mobilenet | mobilenet v2 | resnet18 | resnet50 | squeezenet v1.0 | squeezenet v1.1 | vgg16 | vgg19 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| fp32 | 410.9 | 783.1 | 75.4 | 70.8 | 128.6 | 352.9 | 106.2 | 58.0 | 679.5 | 805.3 |
| fp16 | 280.6 | 460.2 | 49.3 | 53.3 | 84.0 | 215.5 | 72.9 | 42.1 | 410.2 | 479.6 |

Added a test for Shape

In particular, symbolic shapes do not work for the `batch_norm` relation I wrote because it needs to compare for equality (which forces them to be ints): Is that okay, or is there another way I can enforce those equalities?

Add the `where` operator. BTW, I think **where** is not good name for this operator. It actually performs similarly what `blend` instruction does in x86 (https://www.felixcloutier.com/x86/BLENDVPS.html).

title: Allow override gtest library search path
body:
Thanks for contributing to TVM!   Please refer to guideline https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/ for useful information and tips. After the pull request is submitted, please request code reviews from others in the community.

With this change, we don't need to install `gtest` system wide anymore. A typical usage would look like:
````bash
# install gtest into `tvm/lib`
CACHE_PREFIX=. make -f 3rdparty/dmlc-core/scripts/packages.mk gtest
GTEST_LIB=$TVM_ROOT/lib cmake ..
make cpptest -j
````

If `GTEST_LIB` is not specified, it will look for system wide gtest library.

title: Make Rust CI builds faster
body:
This PR

* moves the rust stuff to before the other dependencies in the Dockerfile to make local development easier for most people (i.e. people who want to change the AutoTVM and Go deps)
* adds `sccache` to cache rust builds. makes ci faster by like 3 minutes

title: Enable bool type as storage type
body:
Previously, the bool type(uint1) cannot be directly stored and have to be explicitly cast to int8 before we store. However, it is still useful to introduce the type bool as it is used extensively in numpy and other languages. This PR enables this

- bool is stored as int8 
- storage_flatten pass and buffer is updated to specially handle bool, and do type cast after loading, and before we store.
- The frontend will print uint1 type directly as bool, so the type flag is numpy compatible

title: [Relay][Op] concatenate, reshape, transpose, copy
body:
### OP TODO
- [x] [level 1] relay.concatenate
- [x] [level 3] relay.copy
- [x] [level 3] relay.transpose
- [x] [level 3] relay.reshape

### Misc TODO
- [x] Rebase
- [x] Check sanity check coverage
- [x] Find right file to put these operators
- [x] Re-check docs

### Issues & discussion
- [x] Numpy consistency: [`numpy.concatenate`](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.concatenate.html) accepts ```axis=None```, in which case numpy flattens all input arrays before doing concat, while we do not support ```axis=None```.
- [x] Numpy consistency: [`numpy.reshape`](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.reshape.html) is a subset of our `reshape`. I think it is fine (or even better).
- [x] Flexibility: is it okay that `transpose` directly convert `Array<IndexExpr> axes` to `vector<int>`?

Related issue: #1799

title: Fix saveload json bug
body:
In `saveload_json` pass, a variable node's `parsed` field is not populated. This would result in an exception being thrown at line 37.
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/160eaf5474e064411b7f14ff705042eb603415f0/nnvm/src/core/symbolic.cc#L33-L39

Use the following script to reproduce.
```python
import nnvm
from tvm.contrib import util


def test_variable_node_parsed():
    sym = nnvm.sym.Variable('data')
    tempdir = util.tempdir()
    json_filename = 'test_nnvm_symbol.json'
    with open(tempdir.relpath(json_filename), 'w') as fo:
        fo.write(nnvm.graph.create(sym).json())
    sym_str = open(tempdir.relpath(json_filename), 'r').read()
    sym = nnvm.graph.load_json(sym_str).symbol()
    sym = nnvm.sym.relu(sym)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    test_variable_node_parsed()
```

title: [Relay] More type alpha equality test coverage
body:
Alpha equality is deeply relied on by much of Relay, yet we have very little test coverage for it (mostly lost across different rewrites). I am going to add tests for more cases and in the process try to fix any missing functionality in alpha_eq itself. Please review my tests, as well as changes to alpha_eq, or suggest ways to improve or better organize the tests.

Still to do:
- [x] Have tests in greater depth for type relations and attrs

title: [RELAY][OP] expand_dims
body:
This PR contains a relay operator, `expand_dims`.

TODO:
- [x] Docstrings
- [x] I didn't see a boundary checking for `axis` in [topi](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/0247b97198b0fecf82e6ca44d2f34bc8dfc3540f/topi/include/topi/transform.h#L42). Did I miss anything?
- [x] API inconsistency with [numpy.expand_dims](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.expand_dims.html). Our API looks like `expand_dims(data, axis, num_newaxis=1)`, but numpy API is `expand_dims(a, axis) `. I think it is okay because ours seem to be a superset.
- [x] I implemented `axis` and `num_newaxis` as `int`. Wondering if it is possible to make them `IndexExpr`, so that `axis` could depend on some intermediate result of computation.

I am working on the docstring, and @tqchen could you help comment on the TODO 2, 3, 4?

Related issue: #1799

Edit: dce is merged, and I used alpha_equal for test correctness. all is good.

title: Allow long type values in shape list
body:
I tried to compile resnet18_v1 model with opt_level=2 on ARMv7 Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+ using python2.7 and I got error - "shape value must be int iterator"
code to compile the model - https://gist.github.com/apivovarov/960a28fc1bbd5dbdb856c0ede6724f30

Error:
```
('model:', 'resnet18_v1', ', target:', 'llvm', ', opt_level:', 3, ', data_shape:', (1, 3, 224, 224))
Compiling...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "compile.py", line 25, in <module>
    graph, lib, params = nnvm.compiler.build(sym, target, shape={"data": data_shape}, params=params)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nnvm-0.8.0-py2.7.egg/nnvm/compiler/build_module.py", line 288, in build
    graph, params = precompute_prune(graph, params)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nnvm-0.8.0-py2.7.egg/nnvm/compiler/build_module.py", line 407, in precompute_prune
    out_arrs = _run_graph(pre_graph, params)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nnvm-0.8.0-py2.7.egg/nnvm/compiler/build_module.py", line 356, in _run_graph
    graph, libmod, _ = build(graph, target, shape, dtype)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nnvm-0.8.0-py2.7.egg/nnvm/compiler/build_module.py", line 255, in build
    raise TypeError("shape value must be int iterator")
TypeError: shape value must be int iterator
```

I checked the content of `shape.values()`  (build_module.py line 255) and saw that it contains long values instead of int values.
I was told that int/long types mess is known python2.7 issue on 32bit platforms.
```
[(256L,), (64L,), (512L,), (128L,), (64L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (128L, 64L, 1L, 1L), (256L,), (256L,), (64L,), (512L,), (128L,), (256L,), (256L, 256L, 3L, 3L), (256L,), (1000L,), (64L,), (64L,), (1000L, 512L), (256L,), (128L,), (512L,), (512L,), (512L,), (512L,), (256L,), (128L,), (256L, 128L, 1L, 1L), (256L,), (256L,), (512L,), (64L,), (64L,), (128L, 128L, 3L, 3L), (512L, 256L, 1L, 1L), (128L,), (256L,), (512L,), (128L,), (512L,), (512L,), (256L,), (256L,), (64L,), (128L, 128L, 3L, 3L), (256L,), (128L,), (512L,), (512L,), (64L,), (256L, 256L, 3L, 3L), (256L,), (64L,), (64L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (256L,), (64L,), (64L,), (128L,), (128L,), (128L,), (512L, 256L, 3L, 3L), (128L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (128L,), (512L,), (512L,), (512L,), (512L, 512L, 3L, 3L), (128L,), (512L,), (512L,), (64L,), (256L,), (128L,), (512L, 512L, 3L, 3L), (512L,), (64L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (256L,), (64L,), (256L,), (64L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (128L,), (128L,), (64L,), (64L,), (512L, 512L, 3L, 3L), (64L,), (128L,), (256L,), (64L,), (512L,), (128L,), (256L, 256L, 3L, 3L), (128L,), (64L, 3L, 7L, 7L), (256L,), (256L, 128L, 3L, 3L), (128L, 128L, 3L, 3L), (128L,), (64L,), (512L,), (64L,), (64L,), (128L,)]
```

This PR solves the issue by allowing long type values in shape list.
